result.execSummary:
The defendant Trever J. Sullivan was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Trever J. Sullivan is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Trever J. Sullivan was found guilty of Possession of Narcotic Drugs [Modifiers: Repeater], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: If Probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of governmental agencies for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

miscConds.notes: Pay costs according to a schedule set forth by Probation & Parole.

chargeModifiers.descr: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime
PTAC, as a Party to a Crime

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Trever J. Sullivan

records.addlTxt: Order and Amendment to Judgment of Conviction in Probation Cases - Defendant ordered to serve 44 days jail as a condition of probation
Petition and Stipulation to Amend Judgment of Conviction Probation Cases

08:45 AM Attorney William A. Schembera appeared by video means for Defendant Trever J. Sullivan.  Attorney Jon D. Seifert appeared by video means for Plaintiff State of Wisconsin. Defendant Trever J. Sullivan appeared by video means. Court informs Defendant of charges, repeater enhancer, maximum penalties. Defendant has no questions. Court informs Defendant of his rights.  Atty. Schembera states that his client is ready to plead and the plea questionnaire and waiver of rights is on file. Atty. Schembera and Defendant both agree to Zoom. Court goes through plea colloqauy and rights being waived. Defendant pleads guilty to possession of narcotic drugs - repeater. Court accepts Defendants guilty plea and finds him guilty.  All other charges are dismissed and read-in. Court withholds sentence and places Defendant on two (2) years probation. Conditions to include no possession or consumption of controlled substances and/or alcohol, no entrance into bars/taverns except for purposes of employement. Pay court costs in the amount of $518.00, provide DNA sample. 39 days jail credit. Court informs Defendant of his appeal rights.

03:44 PM Defendant Trever J. Sullivan appeared by video means from the Pepin County Jail with Attorney William A. Schembera by video means. Attorney Jon D. Seifert appeared by phone means for Plaintiff State of Wisconsin.  Called and sworn by State Sgt. John Schellhorn for the Durand Police Dept.  Attorney Schembera stipulates to identification of the defendant.  Cross-exam by Attorney Schembera.  Argument by Attorney Schembera.  Court there is not probable cause there was 2nd degree Reckless endangerment from the use of either oxicodone or meth.  Court does find based on the testimony there were felonies committed and Mr. Sullivan probably committed them for posession of narcotics, oxicoden, possessio of meth.  and Mr. Seifert did put anything in about a prior conviction for Mr. Sullivan.  There were felonies commited and Mr. Sullivan probably committed them and bind him over.  Bond remains as previously set.  Arraignment scheduled for March 1, 2022 at 08:45 am.

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt: Preliminary hearing on February 1, 2022 at 03:30 pm.

02:08 PM Defendant Trever J. Sullivan appeared by zoom technology by video means from the Pepin County Jail.   Attorney Jon D. Seifert appeared by phone means for Plaintiff State of Wisconsin.  Court advises defendant of charges/max. penalties and constitutional rights.  State informs Mr. Sullivan is a MN resident and has a significant criminal history and recent criminal history with all convictions in MN, particularly Hennepin County.  There are a number of times for failures to appear in Hennepin County and Dakota County.  Given the failures to appear, lengthy criminal history, he's not a resident of this jurisdiction, ask for a cash bond of $2500 and if makes that cash bond, prohibit him of possession or use of controlled substance; consume any alcohol or entry into bars or taverns unless he works there and return to this jurisdiction.  Defendant asks to be released on his own recognizances.  The court will order $2500 cash bond and advised defendant of right to PH within 10 days or when it is more likely when he have counsel.  Defendant wants it when has counsel.  Court finds Mr. Sullivan knowingly, voluntarily & intelligently waives time limits for PH.  Defendant requests PH within 10 days.  Court informs Mr. Sullivan to contact the PD office.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for February 1, 2022 at 03:30 pm.
